title: Sport in Turkey
text:
Among all <a href="sport">sport</a> in <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>, the most popular one is <a href="Association%20football">football</a>. Turkey's top teams include <a href="Fenerbah%C3%A7e%20S.K.%20%28football%29">Fenerbahçe</a>, <a href="Galatasaray%20S.K.%20%28football%29">Galatasaray</a> and <a href="Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F%20J.K.">Beşiktaş</a>. In 2000, Galatasaray won the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> and <a href="UEFA%20Super%20Cup">UEFA Super Cup</a>. Two years later, the <a href="Turkey%20national%20football%20team">Turkish national team</a> finished third in the <a href="2002%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2002 FIFA World Cup</a> Finals in Japan and South Korea, while in 2008, the national team reached the semi-finals of the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202008">UEFA Euro 2008</a> competition. The <a href="Atat%C3%BCrk%20Olympic%20Stadium">Atatürk Olympic Stadium</a> in <a href="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> hosted the <a href="2005%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20Final">2005 UEFA Champions League Final</a>, while the <a href="%C5%9E%C3%BCkr%C3%BC%20Saraco%C4%9Flu%20Stadium">Şükrü Saracoğlu Stadium</a> in Istanbul hosted the <a href="2009%20UEFA%20Cup%20Final">2009 UEFA Cup Final</a>.
Other popular mainstream sports include <a href="basketball">basketball</a> and <a href="volleyball">volleyball</a>. Turkey hosted the Finals of <a href="EuroBasket%202001">EuroBasket 2001</a> and the <a href="2010%20FIBA%20World%20Championship">2010 FIBA World Cup</a> the men's national team finishing second in both events. The national team also reached the quarter-finals of the <a href="2006%20FIBA%20World%20Championship">2006 FIBA World Cup</a>, and <a href="2014%20FIBA%20Basketball%20World%20Cup">2014 FIBA World Cup</a>. At the club level, <a href="Anadolu%20Efes%20S.K.">Anadolu Efes</a> (then known as Efes Pilsen) won the <a href="FIBA%20Kora%C4%87%20Cup">FIBA Korać Cup</a> in 1996, finished second in the <a href="FIBA%20Saporta%20Cup">FIBA Saporta Cup</a> in 1993, and made it to the Final Four of the <a href="EuroLeague">EuroLeague</a> in 2000 and 2001 as the first Turkish club in history. In the following years, <a href="Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F%20men%27s%20basketball%20team">Beşiktaş</a> have come out as the winners of the <a href="FIBA%20EuroChallenge">FIBA EuroChallenge</a> in the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20FIBA%20EuroChallenge">2011–12</a> season with only a single defeat, all stages of the tournament included. Later on, <a href="Galatasaray%20S.K.%20%28men%27s%20basketball%29">Galatasaray</a> won the <a href="EuroCup%20Basketball">EuroCup</a> title in <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Eurocup%20Basketball">2016</a>. In the following <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20EuroLeague">2016–17 Euroleague season</a>, <a href="Fenerbah%C3%A7e%20Men%27s%20Basketball">Fenerbahçe</a> won Europe's highest-tier basketball league, the <a href="EuroLeague">EuroLeague</a>, as the first Turkish club ever, which was followed by <a href="Anadolu%20Efes%20S.K.">Anadolu Efes</a> in the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20EuroLeague">2020–21 Euroleague season</a>. Turkish basketball players such as <a href="Mehmet%20Okur">Mehmet Okur</a>, <a href="Hedo%20T%C3%BCrko%C4%9Flu">Hidayet Türkoğlu</a> and <a href="Ersan%20%C4%B0lyasova">Ersan İlyasova</a> have also been successful in the <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">NBA</a>. Active Turkish NBA players include <a href="Cedi%20Osman">Cedi Osman</a>, <a href="Furkan%20Korkmaz">Furkan Korkmaz</a>, <a href="Enes%20Kanter">Enes Kanter</a> and <a href="Ersan%20%C4%B0lyasova">Ersan Ilyasova</a>.
Women's volleyball teams, namely <a href="Fenerbah%C3%A7e%20Women%27s%20Volleyball">Fenerbahçe</a>, <a href="Eczac%C4%B1ba%C5%9F%C4%B1%20VitrA">Eczacıbaşı</a> and <a href="Vak%C4%B1fbank%20S.K.">Vakıfbank</a>, have won numerous <a href="CEV%20Women%27s%20Champions%20League">European championship</a> titles and medals. <a href="Vak%C4%B1fbank%20S.K.">Vakıfbank</a> is currently one of the best volleyball teams in the world, 3 time winner of the <a href="FIVB%20Volleyball%20Women%27s%20Club%20World%20Championship">Club World Championship</a> and 4 time <a href="CEV%20Women%27s%20Champions%20League">European championship</a> winner. The yellow-black team is also the most successful sports team of Turkey in International arena with the title of the most international trophy (9) holder of Turkey. Fenerbahçe also won the <a href="FIVB%20Volleyball%20Women%27s%20Club%20World%20Championship">Club World Championship</a> as the first Turkish club ever in <a href="2010%20FIVB%20Volleyball%20Women%27s%20Club%20World%20Championship">2010</a>. Turkey Women's National Basketball team won the silver medal in the European Championship in 2011 while the Women's National Volleyball Team reached the 6th place in the World Championship in 2010 and won a bronze medal in European Championship in 2011.
Turkish athletes recently achieved success in European level; <a href="Elvan%20Abeylegesse">Elvan Abeylegesse</a> winning gold medal in Women's 10000 metres and silver in Women's 5000 metres, <a href="Alemitu%20Bekele%20Degfa">Alemitu Bekele</a> winning gold medal in Women's 5000 metres and <a href="Nevin%20Yan%C4%B1t">Nevin Yanıt</a> winning gold medal in Women's 100 metres Hurdl in 2010 European Championship. In <a href="2011%20European%20Athletics%20Indoor%20Championships">2011 European Athletics Indoor Championships</a> <a href="Kemal%20Koyuncu">Kemal Koyuncu</a> won silver in Men's 1500 metres and <a href="Halil%20Akkas">Halil Akkas</a> won bronze in Men's 3000 metres.
The traditional Turkish national sport has been the <a href="oil%20wrestling">oil wrestling</a> ("Yağlı güreş") since <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman times</a>. <a href="Edirne">Edirne</a> hosts the annual <a href="K%C4%B1rkp%C4%B1nar">Kırkpınar</a> oiled wrestling tournament since 1361. International wrestling styles governed by <a href="International%20Federation%20of%20Associated%20Wrestling%20Styles">FILA</a> such as <a href="Freestyle%20wrestling">Freestyle wrestling</a> and <a href="Greco-Roman%20wrestling">Greco-Roman wrestling</a> are also popular, with many European, World and Olympic championship titles won by Turkish wrestlers both individually and as a national team. Another major sport in which the Turks have been internationally successful is <a href="Olympic%20weightlifting">weightlifting</a>.
Football.
Turkey has risen to prominence in a number of <a href="sports">sporting areas</a> in recent decades. <a href="Association%20football">Football</a> has seen a rapid transformation earning it third place in the coveted <a href="2002%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2002 FIFA World Cup</a>. Its domestic teams are dominated by <a href="Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F%20J.K.">Beşiktaş</a>, <a href="Fenerbah%C3%A7e%20S.K.">Fenerbahçe</a>, and <a href="Galatasaray%20S.K.%20%28football%20team%29">Galatasaray</a>. Of these, <a href="Fenerbah%C3%A7e%20S.K.%20%28football%29">Fenerbahçe</a>'s European triumph came in the now defunct <a href="Balkans%20Cup">Balkans Cup</a> in <a href="1966%E2%80%9367%20Balkans%20Cup">1968</a>. Galatasaray has seen success after the 1990s, winning the 2000 <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> and <a href="UEFA%20Super%20Cup">UEFA Super Cup</a>. In recent years, Turkey has exported many of its players into top foreign teams, including <a href="Inter%20Milan">Internazionale</a>, <a href="FC%20Barcelona">FC Barcelona</a>, <a href="Parma%20Calcio%201913">Parma</a>, <a href="A.C.%20Milan">Milan</a>, and <a href="FC%20Bayern%20Munich">Bayern Munich</a>, among others. As well as sending players abroad, the Turkish league has also attracted players into Turkey. World class players such as <a href="Pierre%20van%20Hooijdonk">Pierre van Hooijdonk</a>, <a href="M%C3%A1rio%20Jardel">Mário Jardel</a>, <a href="Nicolas%20Anelka">Nicolas Anelka</a>, <a href="John%20Carew">John Carew</a>, <a href="Milan%20Baro%C5%A1">Milan Baroš</a>, <a href="Radomir%20Anti%C4%87">Radomir Antić</a>, <a href="%C3%93scar%20C%C3%B3rdoba">Óscar Córdoba</a>, <a href="Lincoln%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201979%29">Lincoln</a>, <a href="Mateja%20Ke%C5%BEman">Mateja Kežman</a>, <a href="Kleberson">Kleberson</a>, <a href="Roberto%20Carlos">Roberto Carlos</a>, <a href="Zoran%20Simovi%C4%87">Zoran Simović</a>, <a href="Frank%20de%20Boer">Frank de Boer</a>, <a href="Giovani%20dos%20Santos">Giovani dos Santos</a>, <a href="Franck%20Rib%C3%A9ry">Franck Ribéry</a>, <a href="Harry%20Kewell">Harry Kewell</a>, <a href="Daniel%20G%C3%BCiza">Dani Güiza</a>, <a href="Guti%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201976%29">Guti</a>, <a href="Ricardo%20Quaresma">Quaresma</a>, <a href="Gheorghe%20Hagi">Gheorghe Hagi</a>, <a href="J%C3%B4">Jô</a>, <a href="Abdul%20Kader%20Keita">Abdul Kader Keita</a>, <a href="Shabani%20Nonda">Shabani Nonda</a>, <a href="Lucas%20Neill">Lucas Neill</a>, <a href="Lorik%20Cana">Lorik Cana</a>, <a href="Gheorghe%20Popescu">Giga Popescu</a>, <a href="J%C3%A9r%C3%B4me%20Rothen">Jérôme Rothen</a> and many more have played at some point or continue to play in Turkey.
Basketball.
<a href="Basketball">Basketball</a> is also gaining popularity in Turkey. <a href="Turkey%20national%20basketball%20team">Turkey</a> came in second at the <a href="European%20Basketball%20Championship">European Basketball Championship</a> <a href="EuroBasket%202001">2001</a> in Istanbul. Turkey also came in ninth at the <a href="2002%20FIBA%20World%20Championship">2002 FIBA World Cup</a>. <a href="List%20of%20Turkish%20NBA%20players">Several Turkish nationals</a>, including <a href="Ersan%20%C4%B0lyasova">Ersan İlyasova</a>, <a href="Hedo%20T%C3%BCrko%C4%9Flu">Hedo Türkoğlu</a>, <a href="Mehmet%20Okur">Mehmet Okur</a>, <a href="Semih%20Erden">Semih Erden</a>, <a href="%C3%96mer%20A%C5%9F%C4%B1k">Ömer Aşık</a>, and <a href="Enes%20Kanter">Enes Kanter</a>, have played in the prestigious <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">National Basketball Association</a>, generally considered the world's top basketball league. Turkey's greatest success in international basketball came when it hosted the <a href="2010%20FIBA%20World%20Championship">2010 FIBA World Cup</a>, finishing second behind the <a href="United%20States%20men%27s%20national%20basketball%20team">USA</a>. <a href="Hedo%20T%C3%BCrko%C4%9Flu">Hedo Turkoglu</a> captained the national side and made the all-tournament team. Turkey also advanced to the quarter-finals in the <a href="2006%20FIBA%20World%20Championship">2006 FIBA World Cup</a>, achieving a non-expected sixth place. Turkey reached the quarter-finals again eight years later at the <a href="2014%20FIBA%20Basketball%20World%20Cup">2014 FIBA World Cup</a>. The <a href="Turkey%20women%27s%20national%20basketball%20team">Turkey women's national basketball team</a> won the silver medal at the <a href="EuroBasket%20Women">EuroBasket Women</a> in <a href="EuroBasket%20Women%202011">2011</a>. 
At a club level, the most successful team has been <a href="Fenerbah%C3%A7e%20Basketball">Fenerbahçe S.K.</a> and <a href="Anadolu%20Efes%20S.K.">Anadolu Efes S.K.</a>, the latter having won the <a href="FIBA%20Kora%C4%87%20Cup">FIBA Korać Cup</a> in 1996 and the <a href="EuroLeague">Euroleague</a> in <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20EuroLeague">2021</a>. <a href="Fenerbah%C3%A7e%20Basketball">Fenerbahce</a> currently has the most <a href="EuroLeague%20Final%20Four">Euroleague Final Four</a> appearances (5) and was the first Turkish team to win the title in the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20EuroLeague">2016–17 season</a>. <a href="Galatasaray%20S.K.%20%28men%27s%20basketball%29">Galatasaray</a> won the <a href="EuroCup%20Basketball">EuroCup</a> title, Europe's second-tier basketball league, in <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Eurocup%20Basketball">2016</a>. Past achievements also include <a href="Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F%20J.K.%20%28men%27s%20basketball%29">Besiktas</a>' <a href="FIBA%20EuroChallenge">FIBA EuroChallenge</a> title in the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20FIBA%20EuroChallenge">2012</a>. In women's basketball, <a href="Galatasaray%20S.K.%20%28women%27s%20basketball%29">Galatasaray</a> won the 2008-09 <a href="FIBA%20EuroCup">FIBA EuroCup</a>, finished third in the same competition in 2007-08, and also was runner-up in the 2009 <a href="FIBA%20Europe%20SuperCup%20Women">FIBA Europe SuperCup Women</a>.
Volleyball.
Volleyball, especially women's volleyball is a popular sport in Turkey. Recently <a href="Turkey%20women%27s%20national%20volleyball%20team">Turkey women's national volleyball team</a> secured 6th place at the <a href="FIVB%20Volleyball%20Women%27s%20World%20Championship">FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship</a> in 2010 in Japan, and won a bronze medal at the <a href="Women%27s%20European%20Volleyball%20Championship">Women's European Volleyball Championship</a> in 2011 in Serbia. Turkey's top women's volleyball team is <a href="Vak%C4%B1fbank%20S.K.">Vakıfbank</a>, which have won undefeated 3 Championships at the <a href="FIVB%20Volleyball%20Women%27s%20Club%20World%20Championship">FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship</a> in 2013,2017 and 2018. 4 Championship undefeated at the <a href="CEV%20Women%27s%20Champions%20League">CEV Women's Champions League</a> in 2011,2013,2017 and 2018 season and the gold medal in both <a href="Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> and <a href="Women%27s%20Top%20Volley%20International">Women's Top Volley International</a> in the 2007-08 season. Another prominent Turkish women's volleyball club is <a href="Fenerbah%C3%A7e%20Women%27s%20Volleyball">Fenerbahçe</a>, which have won the <a href="FIVB%20Volleyball%20Women%27s%20Club%20World%20Championship">FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship</a> undefeated in <a href="2010%20FIVB%20Volleyball%20Women%27s%20Club%20World%20Championship">2010</a>, the silver medal in the <a href="CEV%20Women%27s%20Champions%20League">CEV Women's Champions League</a> in the 2009-10 season and finishing in third place during the 2010-11 season.
Turkey featured a men's national team in <a href="beach%20volleyball">beach volleyball</a> that competed at the <a href="2018%E2%80%932020%20CEV%20Beach%20Volleyball%20Continental%20Cup">2018–2020 CEV Beach Volleyball Continental Cup</a>.
Handball.
<a href="Yeliz%20%C3%96zel">Yeliz Özel</a> from Ankara is a Turkish handballer considered to be one of the world's best playmakers from women's handball of its time.
Athletics.
<a href="Athletics%20%28sport%29">Athletics</a> is another fast improving sport. <a href="S%C3%BCreyya%20Ayhan">Süreyya Ayhan</a> set the <a href="Middle%20distance%20track%20event">1500m</a> world record in 2003 and <a href="Elvan%20Abeylegesse">Elvan Abeylegesse</a> set a new <a href="Long-distance%20track%20event">5000m</a> record in 2004. In <a href="2010%20European%20Athletics%20Championships">2010 European Athletics Championships</a> <a href="Alemitu%20Bekele%20Degfa">Alemitu Bekele</a> and <a href="Elvan%20Abeylegesse">Elvan Abeylegesse</a> won gold and silver medals respectively in Women's 5000 metres and <a href="Elvan%20Abeylegesse">Elvan Abeylegesse</a> also won gold medal in Women's 10000 metres. <a href="Nevin%20Yan%C4%B1t">Nevin Yanıt</a> won first European Championship in a sprint race for Turkey by winning gold in Women's 100 metres hurdles. In <a href="2011%20European%20Athletics%20Indoor%20Championships">2011 European Athletics Indoor Championships</a> <a href="Kemal%20Koyuncu">Kemal Koyuncu</a> won silver in Men's 1500 metres and <a href="Halil%20Akkas">Halil Akkas</a> won bronze in Men's 3000 metres. In 2017, <a href="Ramil%20Guliyev">Ramil Guliyev</a> of <a href="Fenerbah%C3%A7e%20Athletics">Fenerbahçe</a> won Turkey's first ever gold medal in the men's 200 metre race at the <a href="2017%20World%20Championships%20in%20Athletics">2017 World Championships</a>, being the second white athlete in history to achieve this feat.
Beach handball.
<a href="2010%20Beach%20Handball%20World%20Championships">2010 Beach Handball World Championships</a> were held between June 23–27 in Antalya. The <a href="Turkey%20national%20beach%20handball%20team">Turkish national team</a> won twice the silver medal at the World Championships in 2004 and 2006, and the bronze medal in 2010. The <a href="Turkey%20women%27s%20national%20beach%20handball%20team">Turkish women's national team</a> also won the silver medal at the 2004 World Championships.
Fencing.
Turkey hosted the <a href="2009%20World%20Fencing%20Championships">2009 World Fencing Championships</a> held from September 30 to October 8 in <a href="Antalya">Antalya</a>.
Fishing.
<a href="Fishing">Fishing</a> cannot be done from any boat without a license, even if you're an amateur. You must apply to have one by submitting some <a href="Identity%20card">I.D.</a> cards and paying a fee 150 Turkish Lira for two years. Details concerning fishing zones, the minimum sizes of fish that can be caught, and the numbers of fish that can be caught per person can be obtained from the Department of Fisheries at the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs. Aegean and Mediterranean seas are rich fishing areas.
Flying.
Plane gliding, hang gliding, parachuting, paragliding and single engine flights are catered for as well as services that provide instruction courses. Best areas are <a href="Fethiye">Fethiye</a>, <a href="Eski%C5%9Fehir">Eskişehir</a>, <a href="Pamukkale">Pamukkale</a>, and <a href="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>.
Motorsports.
<a href="Motorsports">Motorsports</a> have become popular recently, especially following the inclusion of the <a href="Rally%20of%20Turkey">Rally of Turkey</a> to the <a href="F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration%20Internationale%20de%20l%27Automobile">FIA</a> <a href="World%20Rally%20Championship">World Rally Championship</a> calendar in 2003, and the inclusion of the <a href="Turkish%20Grand%20Prix">Turkish Grand Prix</a> to the <a href="Formula%20One">Formula One</a> racing calendar in 2005. Other important annual motorsports events which are held at the <a href="Istanbul%20Park">Istanbul Park</a> racing circuit include the <a href="MotoGP">MotoGP Grand Prix of Turkey</a>, the <a href="FIA">FIA</a> <a href="World%20Touring%20Car%20Championship">World Touring Car Championship</a>, the <a href="GP2%20Series">GP2 Series</a> and the <a href="Le%20Mans%20Series">Le Mans Series</a>. From time to time, Istanbul and <a href="Antalya">Antalya</a> also host the Turkish leg of the <a href="F1%20Powerboat%20Racing">F1 Powerboat Racing</a> championship; while the Turkish leg of the <a href="Red%20Bull%20Air%20Race%20World%20Series">Red Bull Air Race World Series</a>, an <a href="air%20racing">air racing</a> competition, takes place above the <a href="Golden%20Horn">Golden Horn</a> in Istanbul. Surfing, snowboarding, skateboarding, paragliding and other extreme sports are becoming more popular every year.
The <a href="Istanbul%20Racing%20Circuit">track</a> located at Istanbul has a <a href="seating%20capacity">seating capacity</a> of 155,000 people (biggest in Europe), is just over 5,340 m long and runs anti-clockwise. The track was designed by <a href="Hermann%20Tilke">Hermann Tilke</a>, designer of the <a href="Sepang%20International%20Circuit">Sepang</a>, <a href="Bahrain%20International%20Circuit">Bahrain</a> and <a href="Shanghai%20International%20Circuit">Shanghai</a> tracks.
<a href="GP2%20series">GP2 series</a> also include a Turkish Team (<a href="Petrol%20Ofisi%20FMS%20International">Petrol Ofisi FMS International</a>) and a Turkish Driver, <a href="Jason%20Tahincioglu">Jason Tahincioglu</a>.
<a href="Kenan%20Sofuo%C4%9Flu">Kenan Sofuoğlu</a> became <a href="Supersport%20World%20Championship">world champion in Supersport</a> three times in 2007, 2010, and 2012.
Rafting.
Turkey's rivers provide perfect conditions for canoeing and rafting, for both beginners and experienced. Some of the best rivers for rafting are <a href="%C3%87oruh">Çoruh</a>, <a href="Barhal">Barhal</a>, <a href="Berta%20River">Berta</a>, <a href="F%C4%B1rt%C4%B1na">Fırtına</a>, <a href="%C3%87olakl%C4%B1">Çolaklı</a>, <a href="K%C3%B6pr%C3%BC%C3%A7ay">Köprüçay</a>, <a href="Manavgat">Manavgat</a>, <a href="Dragon">Dragon</a>, <a href="G%C3%B6ksu%20%28Silifke%29">Göksu (Silifke)</a>, <a href="Zamanti">Zamanti</a>, <a href="G%C3%B6ksu%20%28Feke%29">Göksu (Feke)</a>, <a href="K%C4%B1z%C4%B1l%C4%B1rmak%20River">Kızılırmak</a>, and <a href="Dalaman%20%C3%87ay%C4%B1">Dalaman Çayı</a>.
Rugby league.
Rugby League is a relatively new sport in Turkey, so far five clubs make up the rugby league in Turkey, observer status within the <a href="Rugby%20League%20European%20Federation">Rugby League European Federation</a> is expected within a few months.
Sailing and boat trips.
Turkey has four bordering seas; the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a>, <a href="Marmara%20Sea">Marmara Sea</a>, <a href="Aegean%20Sea">Aegean Sea</a>, and <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>, so it not surprising that cruising is a popular sport. There are many cruising charters available. Gulets are traditional motor yachts and gulet holidays are becoming increasingly popular.
Weightlifting.
<a href="Olympic%20weightlifting">Weightlifting</a> has been another successful sport for Turkey, regularly relied upon to provide gold medals in the <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympics</a>. Its most famous <a href="List%20of%20Turkish%20weightlifters">weightlifters</a>, <a href="Naim%20S%C3%BCleymano%C4%9Flu">Naim Süleymanoğlu</a> and <a href="Halil%20Mutlu">Halil Mutlu</a>, are only two of four weightlifters in the world to have won three gold medals in three Olympics, and among women <a href="Nurcan%20Taylan">Nurcan Taylan</a> broke one world record.
Windsurfing.
The bays around <a href="%C3%87esme">Çesme</a>, <a href="Ala%C3%A7at%C4%B1">Alaçatı</a>, <a href="Bodrum">Bodrum</a>, and <a href="Dat%C3%A7a">Datça</a> peninsulas as well as Antalya have ideal wind conditions for windsurfing. Famous windsurfer <a href="%C3%87a%C4%9Fla%20Kubat">Çağla Kubat</a> is also from Turkey.
